fr.sorbonne_u.components.examples.cps.components

Class ValueConsumer

  • java.lang.Object
    • fr.sorbonne_u.components.AbstractComponent
      • fr.sorbonne_u.components.examples.cps.components.ValueConsumer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ComponentI

    public class ValueConsumer
extends AbstractComponent
    The class ValueConsumer implements a component that uses the integer value providing service defined by the interface ValueProvidingI by getting ten values, computing their mean and printing the result on the terminal.

    Description

    This component is meant to illustrate the usage of the continuation-passing style to free the calling component thread when a call to another component is synchronous. Instead of using the component thread to make the call and block it until the result is returned, a temporary thread is created to do so and the remaining code that required the result is put in a "continuation" method which will be called with the result and executed using a component thread. The methods that show the technique are computeAndThenPrint and its continuation computeAndThenPrintContinuation.

    Invariant

     invariant              numberOfIterationsLeft >= 0

    Created on : 2018-03-17

    Author:
    Jacques Malenfant

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  ValueConsumer.ComputeAndThenPrintContinuation
      The class ComputeAndThenPrintContinuation implements the continuation for computeAndThePrint to sum the current value with the sum of other processed values which is received as parameter when called.
      static class  ValueConsumer.ComputeAndThenPrintFinalContinuation
      The class ComputeAndThenPrintFinalContinuation implements the final continuation for computeAndThePrint that simply output the result to the component tracer.

      • start

        public void start()
           throws ComponentStartException
        Description copied from interface: ComponentI
        start the component; this method is automatically called by the component virtual machine after all components have been initialised and the component calls in turn its own inner components. Implementations of this method must always return the control.

        Contract

         pre    this.isInitialised()
 post   this.isStarted()

      • execute

        public void execute()
             throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: ComponentI
        execute a task on the component after all components have been started; this method is automatically called by the component virtual machine after all components have been started and the component calls in turn its own inner components. Implementations of this method can keep the control as long as they wish (contrary to start) but they need to begin by a call to super if inner components also have an execute method to be called; it is the responsibility of programmers to make sure that this does not provoke deadlocks.

        Contract

         pre    this.isStarted()
 post   true                    // no postcondition.
        Specified by:
        execute in interface ComponentI
        Overrides:
        execute in class AbstractComponent
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - todo.
        See Also:
        AbstractComponent.execute()
